This isn't to use an ad homine attack, as much to say that this can't be 
used as evidence of any large scientific consensus. This is a society of 
conservatives, not an official body.

That being said, their main opposition seems to be childhood interventions. 
This is something I agree with. I have no objection to their skepticism for 
trans surgery and hormone treatment in children, but I was mainly talking 
about adults.

The rest they are saying is fairly irrelevant. It doesn't matter if you're 
not born with a gender identity. What does matter is how we best treat 
people who end up developing gender dysphoria.

They may consider it delusional thinking, but I disagree. Most trans folk 
have insight and understand that they are men, but just that they wish to 
act and be a female. I don't think any of them are actually delusional, any 
more that it would be delusional for a quiet person to want to act like a 
confident outgoing person.

+blazednlovinit Sure. Obviously there is debate within the scientific 
community, so I will not pretend that there is a worldwide consensus either 
way. What I will say is that my clinical opinion stems from evidence. CBT 
and psychodynamic therapy are ineffective at helping trans people cope 
emotionally with their condition, although transgenderism has large 
variation in its presentation, so it may be more efficacious for some. 

As I understand, gender identity clinics go through a rigourous screening 
process to make sure that those who could benefit from therapy and would 
not benefit from surgery do not go down that route. 

I have seen a couple of papers that demonstrate improved quality of life 
following surgery. I use this to inform my opinion, that surgery can help 
this population. Anecdotally, many people I've heard speak about the 
surgery, reflect on it positiviely and say that they are much happier, and 
that their co-morbid psychiatric symptoms, namely depression and anxiety, 
subsided. 

This is why I believe surgery is a good intervention, for those that are 
believed to benefit from it.

+Josh Blake There are many articulate, intelligent, good-hearted people who

This documentary was made to bring to the attention of a nation the 
difficulties of people going through the problems of these two children and 
their families. There is no place in comments for over the top, knee jerk 
emotive reactions. You should watch it through several times and then 
decide what it tells you, that you did not already know, about the issue 
under discussion. Then, if like me, you want to comment on what you saw, do 
so sensibly and in a controlled way whether you want to express agreement, 
disgust, or anything else. This is what it did for me. To start with I had 
no problem with understanding what people with transgender preferences go 
through. My sister and I were brought up in West End theatre dressing rooms 
from the age of about five or six, so everything concerning alternative 
sexual preferences were explained to us long before we could experience 
anything sexual in our own lives. But there were two extremely important 
things missing from this documentary clip which I hope Victoria gets a 
chance to put right. Firstly no father, or any male who had not started 
life as a female and cross-gendered, was interviewed. I desperately wanted 
to hear the opinion of Lily's father and what he thought when told his son 
wanted to become a girl. I have never felt this way, but I know what it 
would have done to my father if I had. It would have made him dreadfully 
mentally ill. Secondly, what on earth was a school teacher doing 
approaching a parent and telling them of a six year old boy's remarks about 
wanting to cross dress? The law says he should have reported the case to 
the school's medical staff if he really thought there was a mental health 
confusion issue. We should at least be told if this was done because 
otherwise he was guilty of neglecting to look after the children in his 
care and that is a crime. But the point has been made that all children are 
curious about all aspects of sex from infancy and I know this is normal. 
But how can a teacher or parent know the difference between curiosity and 
an actual biological/psychological anxiety neurosis? For that is what 
transgender curiosity has to start out as for the child to want to talk 
about their feelings to others.If they are not mentally anxious they are 
never picked up anyway. But I would argue that if children are allowed to 
do whatever they say they feel like, - would you let your child steal 
because it wanted something you could not afford? - then it would be 
impossible to bring up a child at all. Certainly the two lesbian parents 
could be guilty of abuse by encouraging and enjoying seeing a minor share 
their sexual predilections, but the people most open to horrible abuse in 
this film were never questioned, ie all the other kids at the schools. If 
they had given honest answers to the obvious questions, not least would a 
boy enjoy discovering his girlfriend was also a boy at the age of fourteen? 
a very, very different picture of confused youngsters would have been 
painted. Yes some poor kids are born with the wrong bodies, I feel 
terribly, terribly sorry for them and would help them in any way I could , 
but NEVER at the expense of their own and other children's happiness.﻿
